context: Together these observations demonstrate the link between cholesterol biosynthesis and isoprene production. Elevation of breath isoprene content in our CKD animals was associated with significant increase in serum cholesterol level. Hypercholesterolemia in this model is, in part, due to the associated proteinuria which is known to increase cholesterol production and serum cholesterol level. The elevation of exhaled breath isoprene found in the CKD rats is consistent with earlier studies by Capodicasa et al. who found marked increase in exhaled isoprene in patients with end-stage renal disease and its further rise after hemodialysis procedure. There is evidence that skeletal muscle is an important source of the extra-hepatic production of isoprene. This supposition is supported by the finding of marked reduction of exhaled breath and venous isoprene in patients with muscular dystrophy and its increased levels with physical exercise and leg movement during sleep in humans [30–32]. However, elevation of exhaled breath in CKD animals shown here and in ESRD patients shown by Capodicasa et al. is unlikely to be due to its increased production in the skeletal muscle.

llm_generation.summary: In this context, 2-methylbuta-1,3-diene, which is a component of isoprene, is linked to end-stage renal failure (ESRF) through the observation of elevated exhaled isoprene levels in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) and ESRF. The increase in isoprene is associated with hypercholesterolemia and proteinuria in CKD models, suggesting a metabolic connection between isoprene production and renal dysfunction. The findings indicate that isoprene levels may serve as a biomarker for renal health status, particularly in ESRF patients undergoing hemodialysis.
